Award.AwardTitle: Singularity, Universality, and Smoothness of Random Walks
Award.AbstractNarration:
Random matrices play a central and fundamental role in various areas of science, including mathematical physics, data mining, random noise perturbation, combinatorics, statistics, and theoretical computer science. For example, the Wigner semicircle distribution, which arises as a limiting distribution of eigenvalues of random symmetric matrices in the large-size limit, was first observed in the study of nuclear physics. This research project is a rigorous mathematical study of the phenomena of singularity and universality in random matrices. This research is expected to lead to a more complete and deeper understanding of random matrices, with considerable impact on related areas of science.

Technically speaking, two aspects of random systems will be studied: singularity and universality. This includes the analysis of the repulsion of Wigner matrix eigenvalues and of random polynomial roots, and specifically the study of certain Wegner-type estimates for matrix eigenvalues and, for random polynomial roots, the repulsion phenomenon under minimal conditions on the random coefficients. The goal under the universality aspect focuses on a central limit theorem-type result for the logarithmic determinant of Wigner matrices and certain equidistribution properties of the eigenvectors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project concentrates on two aspects of random systems: singularity and universality.  For the first part, the PI focused on showing that most natural random systems are very far from being degenerate. This phenomenon has been rigourously verified in various contexts involving anti-concentration of random walks, repulsion of random matrix eigenvalues and of random polynomial roots. For the universality aspect, the PI was able to combine techniques of removing singularity with other tools to show for many systems that the overall statistics are usually independent of the local component interactions. Significant results include

(1) Microscopic repulsion between consecutive eigenvalues of Wigner matrices;

(2) Near optimal long-range repulsion of random matrix eigenvalues and of singular values;

(3) Universality behaviour of random eigenfunctions on flat tori;

(4) Equi-distribution of the normal vectors;

(5) Universality of the top Lyapunov exponents of large random matrices.

The methods developed to deal with these problems seem to be robust and useful. In addition to research, the PI was able to develop undergraduate and graduate level courses which cover topics related to the project.
